item.title: Who I Am
item.description:
“Our clan originally had the surname ‘Ai.’ During the late Song Dynasty, due to a taboo, we changed ‘Ai’ to ‘Zhong.’” — From the “Zhong Clan Genealogy” of Jiangxi.

Thus, the world lost a person named Ai Liang. “Ai” originally means “compassion” or “sorrow.” Fortunately, I am not someone who sympathizes excessively with the world. The surname change was, after all, done correctly. According to the Shuowen Jiezi, “Zhong” means “close-fitting inner clothing,” which is extended to mean the heart or inner self, symbolizing sincerity and integrity. Unfortunately, it seems I am not someone with pure virtue. Yet, in the end, I still became Zhong Liang. The surname is from my father, and the given name is from my mother.

Strictly speaking, this section should include my hobbies, academic goals, professional skills, and personal achievements. But after thinking it through, I find that I have none. I cannot match any of those labels. So, I might as well write about the origin of my name. “Liang Zhong” is the greatest—and perhaps the only—label I can claim.
